w:r.w:t: The teacher will teach basic holidays by using TPR, sentence frames, and vocabulary. Students will study these words and phrases: holidays, fireworks, confetti, trees, presents, flags, workers, /new year/freedom/workers
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Recognize, spell, and pronounce the words for holidays
Spell and pronounce common associated words
Use sets of words in complete sentences
Word List: holidays, fireworks, confetti, trees, presents, flags, worker
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: “Today, we are going to be learning about
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word: holidays
Practice pronouncing the soft c phoneme in “celebrate”
Explain to students that there are special days in America (and in other Western countries) that we
These holidays may be different from those in their culture
Spend time on this slide introducing and practicing the soft c phoneme. Circle the c in celebrate
Ask student to pronounce the word celebrate until they are comfortable with it
Pronounce each soft c word: celebrate, city, cent
Pronounce each hard c word: cap, can, coat
vowel of each soft c word: e,
Identify the vowel of each hard c word: a, a, o
Explain that soft c is sounds like an s and hard c sounds like a k
Explain that “celebrate” is a soft c word
Take students through the soft c and hard c words, pronouncing each
Explain that soft c words usually have e and
Explain that hard c words usually have a, o, and u as vowels
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Explain to students that New Year’s Day is celebrated on January 1 in the U.S.
Explain, or ask, how this is different from many Asian cultures (Korea, China), but the same in others (Japan)
Explain that Americans celebrate the New Year with fireworks and parties
Complete the sentence frame with the correct words: new year
Circle 2018 and draw a line from 2018 to 2019
Explain to students that New Year’s Day marks the passage to a new calendar year
Circle the arrow between the two years to indicate the passage of time
Explain to students that Christmas Day is celebrated on December 25 in the U.S.
Explain, or ask, how this is different from
Note that 25-30% of Koreans are Christian, so your student may celebrate Christmas
Christmas is celebrated marginally in Japan, though your student may be aware of it
Complete the sentence frames with the correct words: tree, gifts
We celebrate with a Christmas tree
Have the child repeat. Do the same with
Explain to student that many families celebrate Christmas by putting up a Christmas tree and giving gifts to family and friends.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word: Christmas
We celebrate our faith at Christmas
Explain to students that Christmas is a faith-based holiday that marks the birth of Jesus Christ
Note that 25-30% of Koreans are Christian, so your student may identify with this
Circle the date of New Year’s and the date of Christmas Day.
Ask, “When is New Year’s Day?” Encourage the child to circle the date. Encourage them to say the date, January 1st. Repeat with Christmas Day.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word: Parties
Explain to students that Independence Day is celebrated on July 4 in the U.S.
Explain that marks the day on which the US became a sovereign nation
Explain, or ask, how this is different from their culture
Korea celebrates Liberation Day on March 1; Japan does not celebrate
Complete the sentence frame with the correct words: flag and fireworks
We celebrate with our flag and fireworks
Explain to students that we celebrate Independence Day by displaying our national flag
Explain to students that fireworks are a common Independence Day tradition
We celebrate our freedom on Independence Day
Explain to students that we celebrate Independence Day to mark the birth of our nation
Explain to students that the Statue of Liberty is a symbol of freedom in the US
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word: Picnics and parades
Explain to students that Labor Day is celebrated in September in the U.S.
it is a special day to recognize the hard work that many people do for the good of others and the nation
Explain, or ask, how this is different from their culture
Note that many Asian countries (Korea and Japan) celebrate International Workers (Labor) Day on May 1, as do many other countries around the world
Labor Day is considered the “end” of summer in the US and is celebrated with picnics and parades
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word: Labor
We celebrate workers on Labor Day
Explain to students that teachers, police, nurses, clerks, etc. are workers
Prompt students to identify any workers they see in the picture
Match the correct soft c/hard c sight word
Pronounce each word as it is matched
Guide students through an initial example by recalling the vowel matches
Circle the appropriate vowel as a prompt, and then prompt the student to identify the correct phoneme
Continue to guide students as necessary
Complete the sentence frames with the correct words: Workers and Freedom
On Labor Day, we celebrate workers.
On Independence Day, we celebrate freedom.

Complete each sentence frame with the correct noun and holiday
I see gifts on Christmas Day
I see fireworks on New Year’s Day
I see workers on Labor Day
